when i tried to make the lemon battery work (The one where you stacked the foil-coin-tissue) it didn't work. I think that happened because the lemon has a lot of electrons so that makes it have a negative charge. When you soak the paper towel in the lemon juice the lemon juice gets all over everything else so maybe the electrons are spreading too. Then once the electrons get all over everything else it becomes a negative charge. So the tube that has all the stuff in it doesn't have any positive charge and it needs both. Therefore it cannot work. If we tried to do it again, maybe instead of just slapping on the paper towel we could wring the paper towel out before we put it on and that way the electrons might not spread so easily.

{[I need to understand]:  Why is some metal magnetic and some not?}
We experimented with some metals, and here are our findings:
- The 1996/1986 nickels/zinc aren't magnetic. (Maybe because they couldn't get the right material.)
- The copper is not magnet.
- A table showing magnet power of metals (below).

Metal	Power
GS	3
A	1
C	1
N	6
I	5
Z	4
(6 = a ton, 1 = _none_)

An atomic bomb works by making a chain reaction.
A chain reaction is a combination of continous nuclear fission reaction because the nuclear resulting: 

U235 + neutron = Huge energy.

Fun facts: Did you know another name for a chain reaction is a nuclear fission?

{[My theory]:  A magnet throws off a compass because all magnets have a magnetic field and compasses are very sensitive to magnetic fields.}

[picture: the magnet makes the needle of the compass point to the magnet.]

Our problems:
1. Why are there protons and neutrons in the nucleus? Do they need to be there?
2. Are there other types of charges that we do not know about?
3. What is light? Where does it come from? Why does a static shock create light?
4. Do atoms contain energy? How dod they do it? How does an atomic bomb work?
5. Can atoms and their electrons be created or destroyed? How can we do this?
6. How do magnets work? Why do they throw compasses off?
7. What are electrons made out of? Is there something smaller?

What we need to do ...
1. Invite a scientist to come and speak about atoms.
2. We should dissect a battery and try to use the insides to power different objects.
3. We should cut a magnet open to see if it still works.
4. We should look deeper into how light works. What is it? How does it function?
5. Experiment with different types of metals. Which one is more magnetic.
6. What is the connection between magnets and electricity?

We tried to make fire with a flashlight through a magnifing glasses but it didn't work because you need solar power.

- Atoms can be divided into smaller particles.
- Protons and neutrons can be seperated from each other. Also they are made of smaller particles which is called quarks.
- You can make atoms smaller by exploding them.
- Only electrons cannot be splitted.

- Neutrons are made of two down quarks and one up quarks.
- Up quarks have a charge of +2/3.
- A proton is two thousands times heavier than an electron. Neutrons are 1,839 times heavier than one electron.
- Down quarks are the second lightest, the first lightest is up quarks.
- Down quarks are fermions, which mean no two of them can not be in the same space at the same time.
- Up quarks are so small that scientists believe they can not be divided any more.
